ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed skills in Blender 3D modeling and rendering, 3D scanning/photogrammetry, using the Unity editor and building VR spaces. It was an incredibly multidisciplinary opportunity that I am sure will have limitless applications in my academic, creative, and professional future!

- learned software such a blender, unity, meta for the oculus
- experimented with a wide range of representation, including VR, photogrammetry, BEEM lab in the architecture school
- learned about digital artists and their differing methodologies and philosophies
- lots of hard skills in terms of 3D modelling and rendering were gained

The tools we used are Blender, Unity, and VR headset. They're pretty complicated technical softwares, but Alvin so meticulously stepped us through the basics and even made customized PDF tutorials for some special functions depending on students' projects' needs. He also often stayed after class to help me debug. I really appreciated how half of class time was dedicated to learning technical skills and the other half was dedicated to looking at artists who work with 3D modelling, VR, and other forms of immersive or technological art. It's perfect for class meeting twice a week for just 2 hours. So there was never a boring class or a class that was too long. I don't think I would've learnt half as much as I did without Alvin.
how to use Blender, Unity, VR etc.

Obtained a good foundation in Blender. Learned how to export Blender models into Unity, then make a VR experience out of it.
Made me think about what I would like to do for a career.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It's obviously technically demanding with a high learning curve, and lots of time is spent troubleshooting technology. Additional support for the instructor on tech troubleshooting (especially once you get to the VR unit) could be super helpful!

strengths: - learned a lot about 3D modelling that I would not have had the motivation to learn myself. course was also structured around three different projects, and this was crucial in maintaining a storyline/ thread throughout the semester as we wove in between different softwares and hardwares. 
weaknesses: technology has problems and you have to be ready to face crashes

Strengths: Alvin's willingness to help, explain patiently technical skills, and give artistic inspiration. Well-organized with a class Discord server where Alvin communicated regularly and put reminders, clear syllabus timetable and deadlines and items to submit, well-timed technical classes vs. artistic classes vs. critiques
Weakness: Need a TA to ease Alvin's burden of helping so many students debug. Also, this class needs a part 2 or to be split into 2 otherwise too much content too fast limits the feasibility of projects. Some more feedback during project progress critiques so they don't seem like they're just for keeping us on track.

Strengths: the content, the professor, laidback atmosphere, not very demanding
Weakness: we do spend a lot of time troubleshooting weird Blender features which ends up taking away from learning new things

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 100% Yes, but they have to be actually willing to put in the incremental work to get better and better. If you come in as a beginner, you can absolutely learn 3D Modeling (Blender), Rendering, Photogrammetry, and Unity skills you did not have before!

Yes! Especially if you are into 3D modelling or are looking to get into it (this is essential to the course as it is in the name). Also what was great about this course is that students came from all different departments such as art, architecture, engineering, film studies, CPAR etc... so everyone had different perspectives and ideas on 3D modelling. In the end, everyone's projects were unique to them and that is a beautiful thing.
Be ready learning new software and train them by making something
Highly recommended for anyone and everyone. A unique experience on this campus. I hope Alvin will be teaching. He is the GOAT!
